title: 105_hr4072
content: The Act titled "Higher Education Family Opportunity Act of 1998" introduces a new section allowing for a deduction for postsecondary tuition and related expenses in place of the Hope and Lifetime Learning Credit. The Higher Education Family Opportunity Act of 1998 introduces a deduction for postsecondary tuition and related expenses for individuals. The deduction is limited based on the deductible limit for each eligible student, as determined by a specific table. The Higher Education Family Opportunity Act of 1998 introduces a deduction for postsecondary tuition and related expenses for individuals. The deductible limit for taxable years starting in 1999 is $5,000, increasing annually until reaching $10,000 in 2009 and thereafter. The deduction for postsecondary tuition and related expenses increased annually from $5,000 in 1999 to $10,000 in 2009 and beyond. The terms 'qualified tuition and related expenses' and 'eligible student' have the same meanings as defined in section 25A. The deduction under section 222 is not considered a miscellaneous itemized deduction. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 amended the tax code by adding a new subparagraph (L) regarding the omission of a correct TIN required for higher education expenses. Additionally, a clerical amendment was made to the table of sections for part VII of the tax code. The Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 amended the tax code to include a deduction for postsecondary tuition and related expenses instead of the Hope and Lifetime Learning credit. The effective date for these amendments is expenses paid or incurred after December 31, 1998, for education provided in academic periods starting after that date.
